text:
Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls,
welcome to another episode with my
friend Ale Ivanova Style

This is Kick The Grind´s Channel,
thank you for watching.

So I met Ale, in Mexico City where we are
right now, where we both been living for quite a while

about two years ago?
- Yes

- About two years ago I'm also a foreigner
living here in Mexico, I'm Russian

and I thought that it would be a
really really really really cool idea to

get together, two extranjeros güeros in
Mexico to tell the real deal because my

family I don't know about your family my
family was terrified when I said I was

moving to Mexico City, because the
world thinks that kidnapping, drug

violence, just the filth of the world
lives here and just shoots each other

and kidnaps each other and this is
terrible; we have fall in love with the

city and I thought we´d put a
list together of five things to

keep in mind, would you come here and
also why we love the country.
It´s so, so

much more than all this problems, you
imagined; it's a beautiful country

beautiful nature, a lot of history, a lot
of delicious food, a lot of great people

and this is one of the top places I
would recommend you to visit. -A hundred a

hundred percent. -Yeah. -I moved here
because I have never seen such a high

density of amazing beautiful cool
interesting unique things in my entire

life
and pick a category could be like

landscape and nature, could be history,
could be culture, could be food, it could

be anything; Mexico is a gold mine and
unfortunately it's very poorly

represented in the media.
-Unfortunately. Question number one! -Hit me

-Okay Mike, have you had any bad
experience here in Mexico something that

you would say: Oh my god, I would never
expect it happened to me? - My only bad

experience has been and this is one of
the things in Mexico as a whole I love

the country this is the only thing that
I don't know how to deal with and I

really don't like, is the situation with
the police officers.

-Okay. - And I feel it's very similar to how
a restaurant works and they might not

seem like they go together at all
but if I own a restaurant I have

employees that wait tables, they bring
food out, right?. -Okay

-Those employees make tips, people
buy that food, they like the food, they give

extra money. So as an owner of a restaurant,
I don't have to pay them as much because,

hey, I can pay them a bit. They get more
money from customers, they get a good

salary I kind of save some money; so why
would I pay them more?. I feel like it's a

bit same with the police. So the police
don't get paid enough and therefore they

have to find their tips and honestly
it's in quite amoral and sometimes

illegal. -The only difference is that in the
restaurant you give tip because you like

the service. It´s not like this in Mexico. -No, you give
a tip because you're trying to get out

of some bogus bullshit fine or something
like that, and it happened to me, I was

in Quintana Roo, which is a very safe
state, very awesome state, Cancun

or Tulum or Playa del Carmen is; I was
driving my rental, car cuz I do drive a

lot in Mexico from state to state and I
got pulled over by a police officer

saying I was speeding everyone was going
the same speed it was bumper-to-bumper

traffic and he said: " you have to pay the
fine, it's three hundred US dollars" and I

said: "what!?" - That's too much definitely.
-And he's like, "okay well, the police

station is closed, this traffic is really
bad, you got to pay me cash right now", and

I had heard about this before and
basically what we're trying to do now is

give you information so if something
that you hear about in this video

happens you can use the information. And
fortunately a friend told me that's

happened, so I I knew, I had a feeling
that when I couldn't pay with I couldn't

go actually pay the fine at the station
he wasn't giving me a paper he just wanted

cash, I was being extorted basically, so
it ended up me saying: "I have no money -I

said- my credit cards were declined, my
bank card was declined"; I couldn't get

money out of the ATM that was
conveniently beside us. He said: "Is there

anything in your suitcase that you can
pay the fine with?"

and I said: "No you can't have my shoes
or my watch", Jesus!, and he got mad, I

found 20 pesos which is a dollar, I gave it
to him and he was furious but he left

-Yeah that's interesting stuff,
I think that here in Mexico, Mexican

people don't really trust the police. -Mm-hmm, I
agree. - We as foreigners, like I have

never had any bad experience with police
but yeah, probably not, like you

cannot see them as a "help", help you say?,
is like in any other

country because like if something bad
happened to me I would, first thing, I

would do, is go to the Police, probably in Mexico
is not the best thing to do. -Yeah, which

is frustrating. Okay, question number two:
if we take crazy things like kidnapping

and drug violence off the table, because
really, as a tourist you don't ever

really experienced that unless you're
selling; are you selling drugs?. -Me?, no.

-Would you sell drugs?. -No! -Well then I
think it´ll be okay. - If you don't have

anything to do with drug dealers, if
you don't sell drugs, if you don't make

commerce of the drugs, you would not get
in trouble with drug dealers it's just a

total different world, and you're
not involved in it

as a tourist, as a person who
is visiting Mexico. - Sure, there

are places that if you do certain things
you could get in trouble, but from my

experience, being in these places with
drug violence, if you just do normal

human being things like see tourist
attractions, go out during daylight hours,

don't wear flashy jewelry and stuff,
generally there's not too much a problem

at all.
-Question number three! Okay Mike you have

mentioned that you have made a lot of
road trips in Mexico. I've heard that

it's dangerous, so tell us about your
experience. What do you think?

-Totally, so getting around Mexico is really
easy because a lot of airlines like

Interjet and Aeromexico offer some
pretty decent cost flights,
I really prefer road trips, and that was probably pretty scary for a lot

of people, when I said that to my family...
-For me also, I have done some road trips I haven't had

any bad experience but I've heard that
it's like you know... -And there are bad

experiences that happen; however
every single bad experience that i´ve heard

of happening, happens between 1:00
a.m. and 4:00 a.m. on the free

highway; so in Mexico, there's two kinds of
highways: there is the "cuota" the paid highways,

and the "Libre", the free highways.
Cuota is more direct you pay, like you

pay maybe fifteen US dollars for four
hours in a car, it's expensive but the

highways are gorgeous, and the Libres
are long windy roads that are free; so,

I love road trips like I said I've
traveled to Michoacán,  I traveled to

Guerrero, I traveled to Puebla, traveled all over
all different states by car, and the tip

I have is: Don't drive at night unless
you have to. I have driven at night but

only for the first few hours after
sunset.

I would never drive anywhere near
midnight, especially not on the free

highways.
I always pay the extra few bucks for my

security driving on the paid highways
during daylight hours and I don't think
I've never heard of anything happening, anyway you're very safe

driving, just being in a car is dangerous
anyway but I would not figure it out any

problems driving the daylight hours, I've
never heard of anything and I don't ever

worry about driving in daylight hours
on the paid highways, so no nighttime

driving . Question number 4: What would be your top tip
for people just to take care of

themselves, there's something that
commonly happens to you here that you

people might want to know before they
come. -I would definitely recommend you to use

cash, so don't use too much your cards
especially in the strange places, I mean

like if it's ATM somewhere in the middle
of the street probably I wouldn't use it

and also when you pay with your card you
can definitely do it in some restaurants,

in some shops, somewhere else, in the gas
station, but when you do it, you always

have to look at your card; never give
them the card and say okay just do

whatever you want with my card and just
give it back to me like in two minutes, no!,

you should always be very aware of your card 
and just look at it all the time.  -I've had two
instances where my card details had been compromised on my credit card

and that is from... I'm pretty sure that
maybe someone having two machines or

or them taking it away for a second and I was
talking to somebody else not paying

attention I now after those two
instances I always make sure I stare at

the guy basically when he's processing
the card, and make him know I'm watching

him, just in case.
-Question number five I have for you Mike;

you know, you have heard a lot about
kidnapping and all this drug dealers stuff,

what do you think of it ?. -I think
the number one concern people come into

Mexico is kidnapping because they talk about
a lot, and I have not heard of, in my

my world ; heard of anything that ever
being an issue. Actually there's two

instances, one Mexican actor who I think
was trying to buy drugs, this only

happened a couple months ago; this is a
very famous actor trying to buy drugs

from somebody and he ended up getting
kidnapped by the drug dealer and then he

ended up getting killed.
That's one real-life example, the other

one is a story I heard when I first
moved here about a year ago, and this is

the story, again I don't
exactly know the details, but it was someone who

worked at Microsoft, and Microsoft was a
very well-known building and of course

if you're working at Microsoft you have
some cash, right?,

and she called a cab and she went outside to
take the cab and it was fake he said oh

this is the cab and so let her in and it
wasn't and she got kidnapped. I don't know

what happened after that. However, I;
myself here, don't ever worry about that

kind of stuff and there is some drug
violence. Another real-life example is

when I live close to Cibeles which is
not too far from here, it's in Roma

Norte, which is one of the more safe
communities, nicer communities; there was
a club there that someone was shot at. Shot and get killed. Right beside where I

lived but, going back to what we're
talking about earlier, is that this was

drug druggie on drug violence so someone
was selling drugs in a place they

should've been selling drugs and they
got shot for doing so that's happened a
couple times in Mexico also in Playa del Carmen happened and two Canadians got shot in the crossfire.

That is very rare here extremely rare
here and but it does sometimes happen

there is the collateral damage. Again, for
myself that kind of danger isn't someone

blowing up Starbucks you know it's not
targeted towards tourists its target

amongst those different bad groups and
so for me I never worry about that stuff

the only thing I do is worry about
sometimes getting mugged, and so

sometimes I'll put my cash in my pocket
and put my wallet in a different pocket,
so if someone says: " Give me your money"  I give them the wallet. My money is not

there. -That is a good advice. I like it. -And that's
something that I fully expect will

happen me living in Mexico City for a
long time, but if you live in any big

city and like to go to some places that are
maybe a bit sketchy, like I do with my

filming, it just be any knowledge is
the best preparation, right? -That is normal.

-So things like kidnapping and drug
violence and stuff like that I don't

worry about Mexico but it is the number
one concern in it for people visiting

this country it's those type of things. I
have never been in anything where I felt

uncomfortable in any situation like that.
-Neither do i. I have never heard of any

foreigners any friends of mine who were
kidnapped and you know, you have

mentioned that the taxi driver kidnapped
the woman so that's a tip I could give

you; don't use street taxis because
sometimes they cannot be safe just use

any other app, for asking for taxis.
-That's a great tip. I always use Uber

or Cabify. Uber here is so
cheap to get around... Okay! the final

question for Ale: Since I do not have
breasts...yet. -I do. -What are some tips for girls

traveling to Mexico?.  -Okay, tip number one is as I've
mentioned already, don't dress up too

much to not get too much
attention of the men, also in

the public transport if you use it,
They have the women, vagon?

-Sections, yeah. -The women section, so you
don't have to go to the men's section
you can go to the women's section and that way, you would be safer. -And it's pink.  -It

is pink, you know?, also in Mexico you can
see two types of taxis; one of them

is red and the other one is pink
and in the beginning pink ones were for

women, right now I don't think that it
works the same way, but anyway, yes, they

have divided women and
men public transportation,
but I think it works only on the traffic hours

and
also another tip that I could give you

don't accept drinks from strangers
in the nightclubs, in the bars. The only
way you can accept is when you are going together, and you see the

barman serving your the
drinks, so you should be sure that he, not

Mike; the stranger didn't put anything
in your drink. - Okay guys, that is our five

or six tips about visiting Mexico the
the point that I want to heavily

underline and highlight is that this
country is one of the most amazing if

not the most amazing that I visited in
for myself like 50 countries in this

entire world this country is amazing the
people are amazing everything here is so

beautiful, yeah I think they get it, and
I feel like it's an iceberg that people

just think it's piñatas, and it's nachos,
and it's burritos and that is

just... that's the American version that's
Tex Mex it's not Mexican. -Actually Tex
Mex, in Mexico has nothing to do with the other one.

Yeah it's not the same thing.
-The country is so... there's so much to

discover and so much to film and so much
to explore, that we both highly recommend

as foreigners living in a dangerous
place that you've got to come here as

fast as possible before the rest of the
world finds out how super awesome is here.
I wanna say thanks to my friend Ale, for making this video with me she is more

experienced in the city than I do,
 but I'm happy that you have... - I
don't know if I have more experience because I haven't made road trips...

-No, but you've been living
here in Mexico City for three years

longer than me, right? -Yes.  -So I'm happy
because we could put our minds together

and hopefully convince you guys to come
check it out because this place is

awesome.  -Yeah you should definitely do
this.-Experiences over possessions, kick

the grind
check out Ale´s channel, info below and

I'll catch you guys in the next video.
Peace.
